metadata.title: Ball-Milled Carbon Nanomaterials for Energy and Environmental Applications

sections.text:
KEYWORDS: Carbon nanoparticles, Ball-milled nanoparticles, Catalyst, Fuel cell, Battery, Sorbent
■ INTRODUCTION Carbon nanomaterials (CNMs) such as graphene, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and nanofibers possess extraordinary physical, chemical, and mechanical properties for applications in various fields to improve life quality.1,2 CNMs have attracted considerable research interest to optimize and expand their applications, especially with respect to energy and environmental applications such as energy conversion (i.e., solar cells and fuel cells),3−9 energy storage (i.e., supercapacitors and batteries),10−12 and environmental remediation (i.e., removal of heavy metals and organic contaminates from water and soils).13−15 When applied to energy conversion and storage, CNMs have shown excellent electrochemical stability and charge transfer/storage properties.16−20 In addition, CNMs are excellent adsorbents for various organic and inorganic contaminants, including antibiotics,21 PAHs,22−24 organic pesticides,25−27 and heavy metals.28−32 It has also been reported that modification of CNMs can introduce new structures to further enhance their physicochemical properties. Both CNMs
and modified CNMs are promising high-performance structural and multifunctional materials for energy and environmental applications. The properties and functions of CNMs are highly dependent
upon their production methods. Several technologies have been developed for the syntheses of CNMs, including mechanical exfoliation,33 laser ablation, arc discharge, hydrocarbon combustion,34 chemical exfoliation,35 chemical vapor deposition (CVD),36−38 and ball milling.19 Although facile and valuable, some physical methods, such as mechanical exfoliation and laser ablation, possess some disadvantages regarding material purity, uniformity, batch-to-batch consistency, and industrial applicability.39 On the other hand, chemical syntheses of CNMs often involve expensive procedures and toxic reagents that may impose economic and environmental burdens.40 For example, chemical

DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b02170 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2017, 5, 9568−9585
9569
exfoliation relies on acid oxidation of the carbon-rich precursors, resulting in potential contamination risks as well as significant damage of the CNM planes.41 Large-scale production of CNMs and modified CNMs by CVD can be very expensive because of the high cost associated with complex manufacturing equipment and processes.42 In comparison with the traditional CNM production methods, ball milling, a simple but efficient approach which mechanically reduces the grain size of solids to nanoscale particles, has attracted much research interest recently.19,43−45 It has been widely used in large-scale production processes due to its low cost, flexibility, and simplicity.46 A number of studies have also been conducted recently to evaluate the potential applications of ball-milled CNMs (BM-CNMs) in various fields including energy, environment, and biomedicine.44,47−53 Nevertheless, BM-CNM is still a relatively new concept that may introduce promising and innovative technological breakthroughs to benefit society, especially with respect to improving energy and environmental sustainability. The overarching goal of this work is to promote the research on BM-CNMs by providing a critical review of recent research development of the production and characterization of BMCNMs and their energy and environmental applications. The specific objectives are as follows: (1) summarize the fundamental approaches and principles developed in the past few decades to prepare BM-CNMs and their derivatives (i.e., modified BMCNMs), (2) discuss the effect of ball milling on the
physiochemical properties of resulting BM-CNMs, (3) lay out themain applications of BM-CNMs in energy conversion, energy storage, and environmental remediation, and (4) identify critical knowledge gaps and future research needs.
■ PREPARATION OF BM-CNMS As an emerging technology, ball milling was first developed by John Benjamin in 1970 for the synthesis of oxide dispersionstrengthened alloys capable of withstanding high temperature and pressure.54 Ball milling is a powerful nonequilibrium processing method, which refines the grain size of solids into nanoscale after a balance between the defect introduced by deformation of milling and its recovery by thermal treatment.55,56 Table 1 summarizes the synthesis of various types of BM-CNMs. In ball milling, a suitable powder charge is placed in a high energy mill, along with a milling medium.57 The moving balls apply their kinetic energy to the powder charge, break chemical bonding, reduce the particle size, change the particle shape, produce fresh surfaces, and synthesize BM-CNMs by fracturing feedstock particles (Figure 1a).1 For modified BMCNMs, carbon powders are milled in the presence of modification chemicals, i.e., hexane,17 yttrium,58 melamine,59 ammonium bicarbonate,60 magnesium,61 aluminum,62 iron,63 dry ice,64 hydrogen, carbon dioxide, sulfur trioxide, and carbon dioxide/sulfur trioxide mixture;20 thus, various heteroatoms,
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b02170 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2017, 5, 9568−9585
9570
such as nitrogen, hydrogen, carboxylic acid, Al, or Mg, can be introduced to the surface and/or edge of BM-CNMs (Figure 1b). The kinetic energy transferred to the carbon powder from the
balls is governed by the type of mill (e.g., tumbler ball mills, attritionmill, vibratory tubemills, planetary ball mills, and so on), dry or wet milling, the powder supplied to drive the milling chamber, milling speed, size distribution of the balls, temperature of milling, and the reaction time of milling.57 The tumbler ball mill is a cylindrical container rotated about its axis in which balls impact upon the powder through rolling down the surface of the powders. The attrition mill process provide balls and powders a much higher degree of surface contact than that of the tumbler ball mill due to the vertical rotating shaft with horizontal arms (impellers). For the vibratory tube mill, whose cylindrical container is vibrated, the high milling forces are obtained at high vibrational frequencies and small amplitudes of vibration.65 The planetary ball mill is designed to generate both impact and shear forces to the particles.66 Compared to the other ball mills, planetary ball mills are smaller and mainly used in laboratories. A planetary ball mill consists of at least one grinding jar which is arranged eccentrically on a so-called sun wheel. The direction of movement of the sun wheel is opposite to that of the grinding jars. For a planetary ball mill, the high dynamic energies, which are generated by the difference in speeds between the balls and grinding jars produces an interaction between frictional and impact forces, resulting in its higher grinding efficiency and
ability to produce finer particles. Therefore, planetary ball mills have often been used for the preparation of BM-CNMs recently.67
To reduce chemical degradations (e.g., oxidation) and physical fragmentation/destruction of CNMs during the ball-milling process, an inert gas such as argon (Ar), NH3, or C2H4 is often used to fill in the milling chambers for BM-CNM preparation.68−70 Chen et al.71 have developed an approach to prepare curved or closed-shell carbon nanostructures by ball milling of graphite in a dry pure Ar atmosphere. Ball milling was carried out in a conventional planetary ball mill at a mass ratio of steel balls:graphite powder = 40:1 for 150 and 250 h, respectively. Under this condition, closed-shell carbon nanostructures, nearly carbon onions, were obtained by bending of the flat sp2 sheets under the heavy mechanical deformation for 150 h. Liu et al.49
reported the formation of shorter and open-ended multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) by ball milling ofMWNTs. During the synthesis, ball milling of MWNTs was conducted in a planetary ball mill in an Ar gas environment to avoid oxidation of the MWNTs. Milled MWNTs were obtained at a rotational speed of 32 rpm for 10 h. Compared to MWNTs without milling (0.11 wt %), milled MWNTs (0.66 wt %) have six times higher hydrogen adsorption capacity, which is ascribed to ball milling increasing the defects and surface area of short MWNTs. Chang et al.72 reported an approach to prepare Co-carbon nanofibers and Co-CNT composites using ball milling in an Ar atmosphere.
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b02170 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2017, 5, 9568−9585
9571
Using ammonia or hydrocarbon (C2H4 or CH4) as a protection gas, Xing et al.68 successfully prepared graphene nanosheets by ball milling of its bulk crystal. They found that the obtained graphene remained flat and maintained its single-crystalline structure with a low defect density even after a long period of milling time. When modifiers or reactants such as modification chemicals are added to the milling chambers with the carbon powder, one can produce modified BM-CNMs. Jeon et al.73 reported an approach to introduce nitrogen (N) onto the edges of graphene nanoplatelets (GnPs) to produce edge-nitrogenated GnPs (NGnPs) through dry ball milling in the presence of N2. During the synthesis, 5 g of pristine graphite was placed into a 500 mL stainless steel ball-mill capsule at a graphite:balls mass ratio of 1:100. After charging with N2, the sealed capsule was agitated on a planetary ball-mill machine at 500 rpm for 48 h and subsequent exposure to air moisture to produce NGnPs. The resultant 5.67 g of dark black powder (NGnPs) contained at least 0.67 g of N, indicating the fixation of N2 into the GnPs by ball milling (Figure 2a). In addition to gaseous reactants, liquid solutions with modification chemicals are also used in wet ball milling to prepare the modified BM-CNMs. With wet ball milling of graphene oxide (GO) in the presence of melamine, Zhuang et al.74 have successfully developed a nitrogen-doped GO (N-G) catalyst for electrochemical systems (Figure 2b). During the synthesis, 5 mg of GO and 30 mg of melamine were added into 8 mL of deionized water and heated at 60 °C to dissolve melamine. The mixture was then milled in a steel grinding jar with 6 mL of zirconia grinding balls at 500 rpm for 8, 16, 24, and 32 h. After the decomposition of melamine by thermal treatment, the resultant N-G has a nitrogen content up to 32.7%, which is higher than that of the NGnPs prepared by dry ball milling (11.8%),73 CVD (16%),75 heat treating (10.1%),76 gas annealing (5%),77 and plasma treatment (8.5%).78 The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) confirmed the existence of pyrrolic N−H, pyridinicN, graphitic-N, and pyridinic +N−O− functional groups, indicating that the N-G catalysts have been successfully synthesized by the wet ball-milling approach. In another study, silicon@carbon/graphene sheets (Si@C/G) nanocomposites were synthesized by a novel method combining the advantages of wet ball milling and pyrolysis treatment (Figure 2c).79 Expanded graphite, sucrose, and Si nanoparticles were first mixed in a water:ethanol (1:1, v/v) solution. The suspension was added into a zirconia vial at a zirconia balls:raw material mass ratio of 20:1 andmilled for 2 h at 2000 rpm. The Si@C/G composite was then obtained by drying and in situ carbonization of the sucrose coated on the surface of the Si nanoparticles by pyrolysis in a tube furnace for 2 h in an Ar atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/ min to a final temperature of 600 °C. Previous studies have also pointed out some drawbacks of the ball-milling technology to material synthesis, including heterogeneity of the particle size80 and contamination from balls and jars.57 For example, when hard minerals (e.g., quartz sand) are added into the milling chambers with the carbon powder to synthesize modified BM-CNMs, it is difficult to obtain homogeneous grain size due to the difference between the hardness of the minerals and CNMs.80 To reduce particle size heterogeneity, feedstocks of similar hardness should be used to prepare the modified BM-CNMs. When steel balls and containers are used in the milling process, the samples may be contaminated with iron.57 Balls and the container lining of the same or similar alloys as the composition of the samples are often used to minimize the sample contamination. Furthermore, high
energy ball milling could be energy intensive if long operation time is required to prepare BM-CNMs with desired properties. A feasibility test and cost analysis thus might be necessary for largescale practical applications of the ball-milling technology to CNMs.
■ PROPERTIES OF BM-CNMS Ball-milling treatments can bring new properties to the matter depending on the grain size and feedstock compositions.81 In
general, BM-CNMs possess a smaller grain size (i.e., <1 μm for graphene, about 25 nm in height and 50 nm in diameter for CNTs and ∼100 nm in length and ∼8 nm in width for nanofibers),19,82,83 larger specific surface area, better disaggregation, higher dispersing ability,60 and thusmore sorption sites than the feedstock carbon materials. The physical, chemical, and mechanical properties of BM-CNMs vary with the ball-milling conditions. Various methods have been used to determine the physiochemical properties of BM-CNMs.30,84 The surface area, pore size, and pore volume are often determined by the nitrogen adsorption method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) are also used to observe the structures and surface morphologies of BM-CNMs. The crystallinities of BM-CNMs can be identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD) to confirm the existence of modifiers. The magnitude of the surface charge can be quantified by zeta potential measurement. Raman spectra are often used to provide a structural fingerprint by identifying molecules. The dispersive and hydrophilic properties of BM-CNMs can be determined by UV−vis absorption spectroscopy. Functional groups and surface elemental compositions are often analyzed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), XPS, and elemental analysis. Liu et al.49 prepared MWNTs by ball milling and studied the changes in morphology using TEM (Figure 3). Compared with the morphology of unmilled MWNTs, which are curved and twisted together with an inner diameter of 3−10 nm and outer diameter of 25−30 nm (Figure 3a), the MWNTs milled for 10 h are straight and not entangled with abundant particles shorter than 1 μm (Figure 3b). Their characterization results have clearly shown that ball milling can makeMWNTs shorter. Using various characterization methods including TEM, Raman spectroscopy, and BET adsorption methods, Wang et al.85 investigated the effects of ball-milling time on the structure and discharging capacity of MWNTs. They found that increasing the ball-milling time from 0 to 12 h increased the specific surface area and micropore volume of MWNTs from 475 to 824 m2/g and from 0.160 to 0.256 cc/g, respectively. These results suggest that the ball-milling process can increase the amount of shorter MWNTs with open pores (Figure 4a). The authors also found that further
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b02170 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2017, 5, 9568−9585
9572
increasing the ball-milling time to 18 h, however, resulted in a decrease in surface area and micropore volume (587 m2/g and 0.190 cc/g) because of the destruction of the structure and appearance of amorphous carbon and the compaction and agglomeration effects.85 Electrochemical characterization results show that, due to their relatively large surface area and micropore
volume, the ball-milled MWNTs have a large discharge capacity of 741 mAh/g (Figure 4b). A combination of ball milling and other modification methods (i.e., milled in the presence of modification chemicals) can further improve the physicochemical properties of BM-CNMs and even create new structures and morphology. Soares et al.86 investigated the effects of ball-milling methods on the relevant properties of CNTs (Table 2). The ball-milling treatment of pristine CNTs leads to the most significant increase in the surface area (from 291 to 391 m2/g). Among the three treatments (i.e., dry treatment, wet treatment, and external N2-treatment), the wet treatments result in samples with the lowest specific surface

9573
areas. The temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) results of the N-doped CNTs indicate that ball-milled CNTs are poor in functional groups; however, the introduction of N increases the amount of these groups (i.e., pyridine-like N atoms (N-6), pyrrole-like N atoms (N-5), and quaternary nitrogen (N-Q)). Liu et al.87 have developed a method to synthesize Ni@reduced GO (Ni@rGO) through ball milling. In the study, XRDwas used for material phase analysis to determine the presence of new structures/materials by comparing the measured material lattice plane spacing and diffraction intensity with the standard phase diffraction data. The XRD spectra show both the typical (002) plane of rGO and (111), (200), and (220) planes of Ni, suggesting that the Ni@rGO has been synthesized successfully by ball milling (Figure 5a). Using XRD, Esawi et al.62 proved the existence of Al in BM-Al-CNT by the typical (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) planes of Al. Xing et al.1 have developed a method to synthesize nitrogen-doped carbon nanoparticles (NDCPs) through the integration of high-energy ball milling and controlled thermal annealing. The dispersive and hydrophilic properties of the NDCPs were observed by UV−vis absorption spectroscopy (Figure 5b). Compared to commercial graphite and annealed commercial graphite, which quickly precipitate after ultrasonic treatment and indicate no UV−vis absorption, ball-milled graphite and NDCPs are well dispersed in
water and give rise to a strong absorbance band of the aromatic system in graphite over a broad wavelength of 200−800 nm.88 This enhanced dispersive ability and hydrophilicity of BMCNMs can be ascribed to their enhanced surface property and decreased average particle size after ball milling. The increased hydrophilicity of BM-CNMs has also enhanced their catalytic property (e.g., 5.2 mA/cm2 kinetic-limiting current density of NDCPs), which is comparable to the commercial Pt/C catalyst (7.6 mA/cm2). Elemental analysis is often used to determine the presences
and contents of other non-C elements as well as the purity of BM-CNMs, especially the modified ones. Ju et al.63 investigated the elemental composition of iron (Fe) and nitrogen (N) codoped GnPs (Fe@NGnPs) by TEM-energy dispersive X-ray analysis (TEM−EDX); 3.81 atom % of Fe was detected in addition to C, N, and oxygen (O), indicating that the Fe@ NGnPs was synthesized successfully by ball milling. Zhuang et al.74 measured the elemental composition of GO and nitrogendoped GO (N-G) catalysts prepared under various ball-milling conditions (Table 3). They found that C and O contents of GO were 68.72% and 31.28%, respectively, but no nitrogen (N) (0%) was found. Upon N doping, the C and O contents (atomic percentage) of the N-G catalysts decreased as the milling time increased from 8 to 32 h (C: from 62.60% to 47.19%, O: from
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b02170 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2017, 5, 9568−9585
9574
27.12% to 20.07%). These changes can be attributed to the replacement of oxygen functional groups by the doping N from melamine. The N content was increased from 10.3% to 32.7% with increasing milling time (from 8 to 32 h), indicating that the N was successfully introduced into the GO particle. Additional characterizations of particle sizes showed that the average particle size of the N-G catalysts decreased from 887.5 to 312.5 nm when the milling time increased from 8 to 32 h. This change demonstrates the destruction of the GO particles to provide new
active sites for doping N. As a result, the N content increases with an increase in milling time. XPS has also been used to determine the chemical
compositions and oxidation states of BM-CNMs including the N-G catalysts prepared under various ball-milling times (Figure 6). For N-G-8 h (i.e., milled for 8 h), the N 1s spectra in Figure 6a can be deconvoluted into two peaks at 400 and 398.4 eV, which are assigned to pyrrolic N−H and pyridinic-N. A new peak corresponding to graphitic-N can be found at 401 eV for N-G-16
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b02170 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2017, 5, 9568−9585
9575
h andN-G-24 h (Figures 6b and c). TheN 1s spectra in Figure 6d exhibits a new peak ranging from 402 to 404 eV, which can be ascribed to pyridinic group (+N−O−). The XPS analysis results indicate that the formation of pyrrolic N−H and pyridinic-N groups occurs at the early stage of the ball-milling process (8 and 16 h), whereas the graphitic-N (24 h) and pyridinic +N−O− (32 h) groups take a much longer time to form.74
Khan et al.60 investigated the effects of ball milling and milling media (NH4HCO3, NaCl, and sucrose) on the deaggregation and dispersion behavior of detonated nanodiamonds (DNDs). They found that the ball-milled DNDs (Figure 7 b−d) show better dispersion behavior than the pristine DNDs (Figure 7a) in each solvent because of the smaller size and higher energy provided by ball milling. Furthermore, the NaCl + ammonium bicarbonate ball-milled DNDs (NaCl-ADNDs) (Figure 7c) and the sucrose + ammonium bicarbonate ball-milled DNDs (sucrose-ADNDs) (Figure 7d) have better dispersing ability than the ammonium bicarbonate treated ball-milled DNDs (ADNDs) (Figure 7b), indicating that both NaCl and sucrose can provide assistant to increase the stability of DNDs. Ball milling thus has become a fast and controllable technique to promote deaggregation of DNDs in the presence of milling media. XRD, EDX, ERDA, and FTIR analyses have been conducted to compare the physicochemical properties of the pristine DNDs and the ADNDs. For instance, Figure 7e and f show the FTIR spectra of the DNDs and ADNDs. A new peak at 1400.32 cm−1 corresponding to the −NH2 groups appeared on the surface of ADNDs, suggesting that ball milling can efficiently functionalize DNDs.
■ ENERGYANDENVIRONMENTAL APPLICATIONSOF BM-CNMS
BM-CNMs for Energy Conversion and Storage. Dyesensitized solar cells (DSSCs) and fuel cells have been widely
used for energy conversion.89−94 DSSCs are the next generation of thin film solar cell devices.95 They have attracted considerable interests due to low cost, easy fabrication on a large scale, good photovoltaic performance, high power conversion efficiency, long service life, and low environmental impact as compared with traditional photovoltaic devices.96−98 Typical DSSCs consist of three main parts: TiO2 nanocrystalline film sensitized with dye molecules as a working electrode, a redox electrolyte system containing the iodide/triiodide (I−/I3
−) redox couple, and a counter electrode (CE) to collect the electrons from the external
circuit and catalyze the reduction of I3 − to I− at the CE/ electrolyte interface.99 As a significant DSSCs component, CE affects cell performance and efficiency.100,101 Usually, the CEs of DSSCs are fabricated by loading platinum (Pt) on fluorinedoped tin oxide (FTO) glass.102 However, the extremely expensive price and low abundance of Pt seriously limits its application for large-scale commercialization of Pt-based DSSCs.103 Therefore, alternative CEs with low cost, high conductivity, and electrocatalytic activity for the Pt CE in DSSCs are urgently sought. BM-CNMs, which not only have outstanding catalytic and electrochemical properties but also are cost effectively for largescale production, have been shown to be competent substitutes for Pt CEs (Table 4).73,74,104−106 For example, the NGnP-based DSSC shows better photocatalytic activities than the Pt counterpart, namely, a higher open circuit voltage (Voc) (890 mV for NGnP-based DSSC vs 886 mV for Pt-based DSSC), larger fill factor (FF) (74.1% for NGnP-based DSSC vs 70.8% for Pt-based DSSC), better overall power conversion efficiency (PCE) (9.34% for NGnP-based DSSC vs 8.85% for Pt-based DSSC), and slightly higher short circuit current (Jsc) (14.2 mA/ cm2 for NGnP-based DSSC vs 14.1 mA/cm2 for Pt-based DSSC).73 The current density from NGnP (−0.54 mA/cm2) is over 2.8 times than that of the pristine graphite (−0.19 mA/cm2) and comparable to that of Pt/C (−0.52 mA/cm2).73 Compared to the 10 wt % Pt/C catalyst, N-G catalyst-based DSSCs display similar or even higher oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity.74 The onset potential of the N-G catalysts increases with increasing grinding time from 8 to 32 h, and the onset potentials of N-G-24 h (−0.04 V vs Ag/AgCl) and N-G-32 h (−0.02 V vs Ag/AgCl) are higher than the onset potential of the 10 wt % Pt/C catalyst (−0.18 V vs Ag/AgCl.74 It is also worth noting that BM-N-G catalyst had the highest N content (32.7%) than the other approaches (see the Preparation of BM-CNMS section). The higher N content resulted in a larger amount of Ncontaining surface groups, e.g., pyrrolic N, pyridinic-N, and graphitic-N. The N content and the amount of N-containing surface groups are the key factor for electrocatalytic performance toward ORR.76,107 Therefore, ball milling has huge potential on synthesizing N-G catalysts with excellent electrochemical performances. A fuel cell converts the chemical energy from a fuel into electricity through chemical reactions (e.g., reaction between hydrogen and oxygen or another oxidizing agent).108−111 A
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b02170 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2017, 5, 9568−9585
9576
typical fuel cell consists of an anode, a cathode, and an electrolyte. The ORR catalyst also plays an important role in the fuel cell performance.112−114 During the past decades, much effort has been dedicated to the development of low cost, high efficiency, and stable ORR catalysts for fuel cells to overcome the shortcomings of typical Pt-based catalysts, which are costly and are not durable.115−118 Because of their excellent catalytic and electrochemical properties, BM-CNMs have been used for ORR catalysts and have shown excellent electrocatalytic performance in fuel cell systems (Table 5).20,59,73,86,119,120 Compared to a commercially available Pt/C electrode (an onset potential of 0), pristine GR has lower onset potentials (−0.35 V). Upon N doping by ball milling, the onset potential of N-doped GR can reach −0.15 V,59 indicating an increase in the catalyst activity.118 Moreover, the pristine GR shows a two-step 2e-ORR process, while the N-doped GR exhibits a one-step linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curve, which is similar to that of Pt/C (Figure 8),59 suggesting that N-doped GR offers faster ORR activity than the pristine GR.121 Similar results have also been obtained by Jeon et al.,122 who compared the number of electron transfer per O2 molecule involved in the ORR process. Both semimetal antimony-doped graphene nanoplatelets (SbGnPs) and Pt/C exhibit ideal one-step, four-electron pathway (n1/ 44.0) for the ORR, while the pristine GR displays a nearly twostep, classical two-electron process (n1/42.0) for ORR. The
results demonstrate the potential of SbGnPs in fuel cells applications.120
Energy storage devices, including batteries and super capacitors, have also drawn much attention recently because of their striking energy storage capacity and durability.123−125 As a novel material with superior properties, BM-CNMs have also been applied in energy storage devices.126−128 For instance, the N-doped GR from ball milling is attractive not only as an effective metal-free catalyst for ORR in fuel cell for energy conversion but also as an excellent electrode in super capacitors for energy storage with a good operational stability (100% retention of the capacitance over 2000 cycles), low resistance (2.787 ohms), and good rate performance (holding 65.3% of the specific capacitance value of 0.25 A/g at a high current density of 2.5 A/g).59 Sun et al.79 found that Si@C/G nanocomposite, obtained from wet ball milling, displayed enhanced stability and rate performance (645 mAh/g remained after 300 cycles) as compared to the pristine Si (which does not have any capacitance) and Si/G (238 mAh/g remained after 300 cycles) as anode for Li-ion batteries. Xu et al.129 reported that GnPs edge-functionalized with sulfur (SGnPs), prepared by ball milling of GnPs (30 wt %) and sulfur (70 wt %), displayed a high initial reversible capacity of 1265.3 mAh/ g at 0.1 C in the voltage range of 1.5−3.0 V. It also has an excellent rate capability and a high reversible capacity of 966.1 mAh/g at 2 C with a low capacity decay rate of 0.099% per cycle
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b02170 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2017, 5, 9568−9585
9577
over 500 cycles. These results indicate that the S-GnPs outperform the current state-of-the-art cathode materials for lithium−sulfur batteries (LSBs) (Figure 9).129
BM-CNMs for Environmental Remediation. Although promising and with great potential, the applications of BMCNMs in environmental remediation have not been wellstudied.130 Most of the previous studies on the environmental applications of BM-CNMs are laboratory investigations that are still in the exploratory stage.131 Because of their large specific surface area and unique surface properties (i.e., more functional groups),22,53,132 BM-CNMs have been evaluated in several previous studies as a sorbent for the removal/immobilization of various contaminants including metals, radionuclides, oxyanions, and organic compounds in aqueous and soil systems (Table 6). The effect of ball-milling conditions on the sorptive properties of BM-CNMs and the sorption mechanisms of various contaminates on BM-CNMs have also been investigated.15,87,131,133−143 Soares et al.86 compared the performance of novel N-doped CNTs prepared by different ball-milling methods and found that CNT-BM-M-DT (ball milling with melamine without solvent) displayed the highest amount of N functionalities and catalytic capacity for the oxidation of oxalic acid by both catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) and catalytic ozonation (COZ). Under the operation conditions used, oxalic acid was completely mineralized in 5 min by CWAO and in 4 h by COZ (Figure 10). The authors concluded that the N-functionalities played an important role in the catalytic activity of the ball-milled CNTs for liquid phase oxidation reactions. Their XPS results revealed the presence of three types of N-functionalities, namely, quaternary nitrogen, N-Q; pirrole, N-5; and pyridinic, N-6 on CNT-BM-MDT, and the N-6 content was the highest, indicating the dominant contribution of the N-6 groups in the oxidation of oxalic acid. Wang et al.131 investigated the adsorption of aqueous U(VI) onto ball-milled GO (BM-GO). They found that BM-GO showed much better sorption ability to U(VI) than the pristine GO because the types and amounts of oxygen functional groups on the surface and edges of BM-GO were more abundant. The maximum sorption capacity of BM-GO to aqueous U(VI) was 68.8 mg/g.
■ CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE DIRECTIONS With excellent catalytic, electrochemical, and sorptive properties, BM-CNMs have a promising future in energy and environmental applications such as energy conversion, energy storage, and environmental remediation. Based on a critical review of the literature, it can be concluded that the physicochemical properties and the potential applications of BM-CNMs strongly depend upon the ball-milling processes such as ball-milling methods, ball-milling conditions, and modification methods. With the development of nanotechnology in the past several decades, ball-milling technology has also picked up momentum and been successfully applied to produce a variety of BM-CNMs and their derivatives with improved physiochemical properties. Overall, BM-CNMs have been demonstrated to be a unique class of novel and promising materials for energy and environmental applications; however, this review also reveals following research gaps and challenges, which are important for the further development of BM-CNMs and their applications in the future: (1)Only a limited number of investigations have been conducted to explore the environmental applications of BM-CNMs, and more research is needed to develop new and cost-effective strategies for the applications of BM-CNMs in environmental remediation. BM-CNMs, and their applications from both technical and
economic aspects should be encouraged. (3) Various ball-milling
processes have been developed to produce low-cost and high-
efficiency BM-CNMs, and it is critical to carry out further
investigations to optimize the processes for tailor-made BM-
CNMs for their optimal applications. (4) Although BM-CNMs
are promising remediation agents for various environmental
applications, the environmental fate and impact of BM-CNMs
and other coexisting chemicals should be assessed. (5) The effect
of potential contamination from the milling balls (e.g., iron
contamination from steel balls) on the quality of the resultant
BM-CNMs needs to be determined and then mitigated. (6)
While most of the current studies use nanomaterials or their
precursors as feedstocks, novel low-cost carbon materials such as
biochar and hydrochar should also be evaluated for the
production of cost-effective and high-efficiency BM-CNMs. (7)
Economic analysis and life cycle assessment of BM-CNMs and
their applications are also in crucial need of research.

sections.heading: Biographies
sections.text:
Honghong Lyu is currently a Ph.D. candidate in the College of Environmental Science and Engineering at Nankai University, Tianjin, China. Her research interests focus on the preparation of ball-milled biochar and biochar-based composites (e.g., graphene/biochar and FeS/ biochar) for aqueous contaminants removal and bioremediation of organic/inorganic contaminated soils assisted by biochar-based composites. She has published 10 peer-reviewed journal papers in top environmental journals and one book chapter and has applied for three patents. She has received many awards including the First-Class Scholarship of Nankai University for a Ph.D. student, China National Scholarships for Graduate Students, and China National Scholarships for Undergraduate Students.
Bin Gao is a professor in the Department of Agricultural and Biological Engineering at the University of Florida (UF). Before he joined the UF
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b02170 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2017, 5, 9568−9585
9579
faculty, Prof. Gao was a research associate at Cornell University and a
postdoctoral research associate at Yale University. He earned his Ph.D.
in Environmental Engineering at Cornell University. His B.S. and M.S.
degrees were received from Nanjing University in China. Prof. Gao’s
research mainly focus on biochar technology, environmental nano-
technology, and contaminant fate and transport. He has published more
than 170 refereed research articles, one book, and eight book chapters.
He is a recipient of several prestigious awards, including the UF Term
Professorship, UF Research Foundation Professorship, Gamma Sigma
Delta Junior Faculty Award of Merit, Giglia Endowment Award,
FASABE Outstanding Young Researcher Award, and NSF CAREER
Award.
Feng He obtained his Ph.D. in 2007 from Auburn University, Alabama,
USA. He is currently a professor at Zhejiang University of Technology,
China. Before that, he worked as a staff scientist at Oak Ridge National
Laboratory, USA. His research interests include environmental
geochemistry especially iron/manganese chemistry, environmental
application of carbon materials, and environmental mechanochemistry.
Cheng Ding is a professor and an adjunct professor at the Yancheng
Institute of Technology and Jiangsu University, respectively. He earned
his Ph.D. in Environmental Engineering from Southeast University in
China. Prof. Ding’s reasearch is mainly on wastewater treatment,
ecological process of organic pollutants, and pollution control
technology. He is a fellow of the Chinese Academy of Environmental
Sciences. Prof. Ding holds two patents and has published more than 30
research papers in top refereed journals.
Jingchun Tang is with the College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nankai University. He is the Director of the Tianjin Engineering Center of Environmental Diagnosis and Contamination Remediation. He received his Doctor’s degree from Nagoya University of Japan specializing in environmental microbiology and biological solid waste disposal. He analyzed the microbial community of composting using a quinone profile and 16S rDNA DGGE method. Presently, he is undertaking two projects from the Natural Science Foundation of China and other projects from the Ministry of Science and Technology with the Tianjin government. From June 2013−December 2013, he worked as a visiting scholar in the Toxicology Center, University of Saskatchewan, Canada. He was awarded the Yang Asian Biotechnologist Prize, Japan, in 2012. His field of research includes the following: (1) bioremediation of petroleum-polluted soil in an oil field of China using the isolation of effective petroleum-degrading bacteria for soil remediation and the microorganism−plant joint remediation technique, (2) effect of biochar on petroleum bioremediation and global environmental change, and (3) disposal of biological waste using a composting process and agricultural disposal and utilization of fermentation residue (NovoGro).
John C. Crittenden is the director of the Brook Byers Institute for Sustainable Systems and a professor in the School of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the Georgia Institute of Technology. He holds the Hightower Chair and is a Georgia Research Alliance Eminent Scholar in Environmental Technologies. Prof. Crittenden received his Bachelor’s in Chemical Engineering and his Master’s and Ph.D. in Civil Engineering from the University of Michigan. Prof. Crittenden was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2002 and the Chinese Academy of Engineering in 2013. He is the coholder of five patents and the primary author of the text book, Water Treatment: Principles and Design, now in its third edition. He is the author of more than 200 refereed journal articles, more than 100 book chapters, reports, and symposia, and has more than 13,000 citations. Prof. Crittenden’s current research focus is on sustainable urban infrastructure systems. His
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b02170 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2017, 5, 9568−9585
9580
colleagues and he are conducting research on alternative energy technologies, sustainable materials, advanced modeling of urban systems, sustainable engineering pedagogy, and urban form and policy. He also conducts research in various water treatment technologies (e.g., membrane technology, advanced oxidation processes, photocatalytic oxidation, adsorption, etc.) and energy harvesting technologies (photocatalytic water splitting and aqueous phase reforming of biomass).
■ ACKNOWLEDGMENTS This work was partially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (41473070 and 31270544). The authors also appreciate the support from the Brook Byers Institute for Sustainable Systems, Hightower Chair, and Georgia Research Alliance at the Georgia Institute of Technology. metadata.abstractText: With exceptional physicochemical properties, carbon nanomaterials (CNMs) have been widely applied in various energy and environmental applications including energy conversion, energy storage, and environmental remediation. Recent efforts have been made to prepare modified CNMs with improved electrical and chemical properties, hence broadening their potential applications. It is highly desirable to produce high-quality CNMs at a low cost and large scale, which remains a challenging task. Ball-milled CNMs (BMCNMs) are a novel class of engineered materials that may provide new opportunities to satisfy the need. To promote the research on BM-CNMs, this work provides a comprehensive review on recent research development in (1) synthesis of various types of BM-CNMs, (2) effects of ball milling on physicochemical properties of BM-CNMs, and (3) energy and environmental applications of BM-CNMs. Different ball-milling processes for preparing BMCNMs and modified BM-CNMs with desired particle size, structure, and surface properties are summarized and discussed. The physicochemical properties of pristine CNMs and BM-CNMs are compared. Because of BM-CNM’s unique properties, such as excellent catalytic, electrochemical, and sorptive properties, their potential applications in energy conversion, energy storage, and environmental remediation are also discussed. Key challenges and further research needs are proposed at the end.
